none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, January 30, 1883
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, January 30, 1883
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 13 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: J. T. Hand, superintendent of schools in Corsicana, Texas, writes to Professor Louis L. McInnis regarding the state of local public education and his concerns about educational advancement in Texas. Hand reports on school enrollment reaching approximately 700 students and discusses the challenges of developing a comprehensive graded course of study from elementary through high school levels, while expressing frustration with overcrowded grades and insufficient building resources. The letter reflects Hand's disillusionment after 24 years of educational service in Texas, voicing concerns that Texas talent and scholarship are undervalued by those in power, and expressing doubts about his legacy in educational work.

Supt's Office
Corsicana Tex, Jany 30th 1883.

My Dear Professor:
Your welcome Postal
of 28th inst just recd & I hasten to reply.
I recd your letter of December last &
wrote you just before the holidays.
but my letter failed to reach you &
hence may be termed the "missing link".
Our schools are moving on & up I trust.
Our enrollment I think, at the end
of present week will reach 700.
We have excellent equipments but
our grades are all too large for
efficient satisfactory work; & our
teaching force can not be increased
for want of buildings. I am now
engaged in preparing a "Graded
Course of Study" from the A B.C. to
the high School Course & find it no
easy "job" – even after years of
experience – It is more difficult
to arrange than the College Curriculum.
For some months past I have found it

School work and desire. I feel that
Texas talent skill & scholarship
are at a heavy discount with
the powers that be in high places.
I have had ambition to connect my
services & my name with the
higher Educational Enterprises of Tex,
but now see no prospect of ever
realizing hopes I have cherished &
labored for in Texas for 24 years.
Having failed to make money and
failing in this, it seems my
life-work has been - in large part -
a failure. We may moralize as we
please & derive what comfort we
may from even as great a heathen
philosopher as Horace when he said,
Non, si male nunc, et olim,
Sic erit. Facts are stubborn logic
& men of my age can't wait
for revolutions in administrations
policies or tastes. As it was two
or perhaps six centuries ago. "A prophet
is not without honor save in his
own country!"
